lesson.title: Securing Access to Cloud Infrastructure
lesson.summary: After this lesson, you will be able to access cloud resources securely, protect against data exfiltration, ensure compliance, and configure VPC endpoints to keep traffic within your VPC.

atoms.title: Securing Access to Cloud Infrastructure Heading
atoms.text:
## Securing Access to Cloud Infrastructure

In this lesson, we will go ahead and discuss network and server access design methods to ensure network level access to your cloud resources.

By network level access, we mean access to IP networks provisioned by cloud customers using infrastructure as a service including VPCs, subnets, and resources deployed within them such as containers, VM instances, load balancers, database instances.

We will also discuss the ability to log into VM instances and other best practices for ensuring that VM instances are accessed in a secure manner.

atoms.title: ND063 C3 L2 01 Securing Access To Cloud Infrastructure Video
Securing Access to Cloud Infrastructure Summary
atoms.text:
In this lesson, we will investigate best practices for ensuring that your cloud network and server resources are accessed in a secure manner.

Network level access includes access to:
- VPCs
- Subnets
- Containers and VM instances
- Load Balancers
- Database Instances 
- Etc.

Other resources that can be accessed privately from within your cloud private network include S3 buckets, lambda functions, etc.

We will also investigate methods for controlling outbound traffic (egress) from our network to protect against data exfiltration and ensure compliance.

Lastly, we will explore the use of VPC endpoints so that the use of common AWS API's such as S3 does not need to leave your private VPC.

atoms.title: Big Picture Heading
atoms.text: ## Big Picture and Developing Intuition

atoms.title: ND063 C3 L2 02 Big Picture And Developing Intuition
Big Picture Summary
atoms.text:
When designing and deploying cloud networks and infrastructure there are a few key questions to be asking related to security controls:
- Which trusted networks will traffic to your cloud environment originate from?
- Which components in your environment will need network connectivity to other components?
- Are security groups and network ACLs as specific as possible?
- Which components will be taking traffic from the internet? 
- How is access to servers managed? 
- Have outbound traffic needs been identified?

question.prompt: Which of the following considerations are important to ensure secure access to cloud networks and server infrastructure?

answers.text: Try to ensure that sensitive data is never put in the cloud.
Block all access to cloud networks from corporate networks.
Identify and restrict which IP ranges and ports will need access to resources in cloud subnets.
Ensuring that access control is applied at a server level.

atoms.title: Common Practices for Accessing Servers in the Cloud Heading
atoms.text:
## Common Practices for Accessing Servers in the Cloud

In this section, we will discuss a few common approaches to providing console login access to cloud instances or servers.   

While providing console access to cloud instances predicates common actions such as server configuration, application deployment, and operations, providing this access could lead to security breaches in the cloud.

atoms.title: ND063 C3 L2 03 Common Practices For Accessing Servers In The Cloud Walkthrough
Asymmetric Key Pairs Notes
atoms.text:
### Common Practices to Provide Access to Cloud Instances:

#### 1. Usage of Asymmetric Key Pairs 
An asymmetric key pair consists of a public key and a private key. The biggest risk is that end users are responsible for maintaining and managing private keys.

atoms.title: Asymmetric Key Pairs Image
atoms.caption: **Asymmetric Key Pairs**: A User has the Private Key and the Instance has the Public Key
atoms.alt: **Asymmetric Key Pairs**: A User has the Private Key and the Instance has the Public Key

atoms.title: Passwords SSH Notes
atoms.text:
#### 2. Passwords are Enabled for SSH
This is highly discouraged as it can leave the server open to brute force SSH attacks.

atoms.title: Passwords SSH Image
atoms.caption: **Many Vulnerability Scanners Flag this as a Misconfiguration**
atoms.alt: Passwords enabled for SSH or RDP.

atoms.title: PAM Tool Notes
atoms.text:
#### 3. Using a Privileged Access Management (PAM) Tool with Identity Federation 
This can improve security by moving the responsibility of managing credentials and user privileges from the user to a trusted process used by the organization.

atoms.title: PAM Tool Image
atoms.caption: **PAM Tool with Identity Federation**
atoms.alt: Diagram showing usage of a PAM Tool

atoms.title: Native Tools Notes
atoms.text:
#### 4. Use Cloud Providers Native Tools 
AWS provides a service called SSM (AWS Systems Manager). This service enables users to manage EC2 instances at the operating system level. The biggest risk is that SSM also has many other functions which may be used by other users.

atoms.title: Native Tools Image
atoms.caption: **No Internet Exposure is Required and Passwords/Private Keys Do Not Need to be Managed**
atoms.alt: A diagram showing SSM, AWS IAM, etc in an authentication process.

atoms.title: Open Vulnerability Notes
atoms.text:
#### 5. Through an Open Vulnerability  
Oftentimes web servers and applications have security vulnerabilities which allow users to exploit those vulnerabilities with the intention of gaining console access to the instance.

atoms.title: Common practices for accessing servers in the cloud Notes
atoms.text:
#### 6. The Best Method to Log Into Cloud Servers and Instances... 
… is to not login at all! This is called **immutability** and we will discuss it further in a future concept.

atoms.title: Common practices for accessing servers in the cloud Image
atoms.caption: **Just Don't Do It!**
atoms.alt: The best  method to login is to not log in at all!

atoms.title: Common practices for accessing servers in the cloud New Terms or Vocabulary
atoms.text:
### Key Terms

#### Key Pair
A key pair consists of a public key and a private key that authenticate and encrypt an SSH session. The public key can be hosted on cloud servers and the private key is held by the user. Only a user with the private key that corresponds to the public key will be able to authenticate to the SSH server.

#### Privilege Access Management (PAM) Tool
A privileged access management tool provides management of authentication, sessions, password storage, audit, and privilege escalation when it comes to logging into server infrastructure.

#### AWS Systems Manager (SSM)
The AWS Systems Manager service provides the ability to manage EC2 instances at the operating system level - including patching, command execution, automation, state management, inventory.

#### Session Manager
Session Manager is a feature within AWS Systems Manager which allows an authenticated IAM user or role the ability to start a terminal session on an EC2 instance.

#### Open Vulnerability
An exploitable vulnerability in the OS kernel, packages, or applications installed on an instance which could lead to a remote actor gaining unauthorized access.

#### Immutability
A deployment model where components do not undergo any changes from provisioning to deprovisioning.

atoms.title: Common practices for accessing servers in the cloud Easy Quiz

question.prompt: Which of the following methods for providing access to an instance can increase the risk of unauthorized access (and therefore should be avoided)?

answers.text: Use a private key pair and share the private key .pem file with the rest of the developers on the team.  Store it on your laptop or Github repo to use whenever you need to login to the instance.
Set up password authentication on the instance and send the passwords to appropriate parties.
Store the private key safely in a secret management system and set up identity federation with AD or LDAP based authorization for users to login.
Design your deployment in such a way that no one will need to login to the servers for any reason.

atoms.title: Common practices for accessing servers in the cloud Hard Quiz

question.prompt:
Research the following security vulnerability: [CVE-2020-0610](https://portal.msrc.microsoft.com/en-US/security-guidance/advisory/CVE-2020-0610)  

You have launched a Windows server 2019 instance in your AWS environment.  Let’s say an attacker had network connectivity to your AWS instance - which of the following outcomes could be expected?

answers.text: An attacker would be able to login with RDP as a normal user using a brute force attack.
An attacker may be able to run a script on the server allowing them to copy data from disk to an external location.
An attacker would not be able to do anything because this vulnerability only affects Windows server 2016.
An attacker might be able to run a command allowing them to make AWS API calls using the instance's role.

atoms.title: Techniques to provide secure access to servers Heading
atoms.text:
## Techniques to Provide Secure Access to Servers

Let’s look at better methods to provide access to servers and other best practices to prevent unauthorized access.

atoms.title: ND063 C3 L2 04 Techniques To Provide Secure Access To Servers Walkthrough
Image Build Pipeline Notes
atoms.text:
### Techniques to Provide Secure Access to Servers

#### Deploy Immutable Instances
Prevent unauthorized access through deploying servers as immutable components.

Immutable instances are launched from virtual machine images that are created in a private environment. The images have ideally gone through security patching and hardening, custom configuration, application code deployment, and vulnerability scanning.  

When it’s time to update the application, a new image is created and deployed and the old instance is then deprovisioned.

During this cycle no individual ever needs to login to the instance. 

This is a huge step in the right direction in protecting instances from security breaches and unauthorized access.

atoms.title: Image Build Pipeline Image
atoms.caption: **Example of an Immutable Instance**
atoms.alt: A diagram showing an example of an immutable instance.

atoms.title: Configuration Management Notes
atoms.text:
#### Configuration Management Tools

Use a configuration management tool to enforce hardening and configuration policies. Even in the event that someone deployed an instance with insecure configuration, the configuration management tool would override this by applying the correct configuration. Some popular tools with this regard are ansible, chef and puppet.

atoms.title: Configuration Management Image
atoms.caption: **Configuration Management is the Next Best Option**
atoms.alt: A diagram showing an architecture with configuration management

atoms.title: Techniques to provide secure access to servers Notes
atoms.text:
#### Privileged Access Management Tools

The use of a Privileged Access Management (PAM) tool can provide additional benefits such as:
- time based or temporary access to elevated privileges
- granular privilege management
- session recording and audit trails
- password and secrets management
- multi factor authentication

#### Additional Best Practices To Prevent Unauthorized Access
Finally, in addition to choosing a method for providing access, it’s critical to observe a few additional best practices:
- Keep instances up to date and patched.
- Enforce hardening that encompasses security best practices around OS hardening
- Add monitoring for vulnerabilities to ensure that either OS or application vulnerabilities are addressed as soon as possible.
- Implement monitoring and alerting for suspicious events using tools such as intrusion detection systems or IDS or security information and event management or  SIEM tools.

atoms.title: Techniques to provide secure access to servers Heading New Terms
atoms.text:
### Key terms
#### Immutable Instances
Instances that are launched from pre-configured images and do not undergo any changes from deployment to deprovisioning.

#### Configuration Management Tool
Tools that can enforce operating system configuration state based on versioned code templates.

#### Intrusion Detection System (IDS)
A process that monitors system activity and identifies suspicious behaviour indicating that a server has been compromised.

#### Security Information and Event Management (SIEM)
Tools that aggregate system events and logs in order to provide historical and real-time analysis, correlation, dashboards, and alerting.

## Secure Access With Systems Manager
In this exercise, you will use AWS Systems Manager to SSH into an EC2 instance in your AWS account.

1. Create an Instance Profile Role. 
- Refer to the [AWS documentation for setting up an instance profile role](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/systems-manager/latest/userguide/setup-instance-profile.html) for AWS Systems Manager. **Skip straight to Task 2 in this AWS documentation**. 
- You may name the role `cand-c2-l2-instance-role`.

2. Launch An EC2 Instance.
 - When choosing the AMI, use Quick Start and select the Amazon Linux 2 AMI.
 - For the IAM role, assign the name of the role you just created: `cand-c3-l2-instance-role`.

3. Connect to your EC2 instance. Follow the [AWS documentation for Systems Manager](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/systems-manager/latest/userguide/session-manager-working-with-sessions-start.html) to connect to the EC2 instance you have just created.

atoms.title: Controlling network traffic Heading
atoms.text:
## Controlling Network Traffic

So far in this course, we have discussed methods to ensure secure authenticated and authorized access to the cloud control plane and server instances. We emphasized the idea of shifting management of users and roles to a centralized identity provider, providing least privilege permissions, and designing your environment with the least need to provide access to users. 

Inevitably, traffic will need to reach cloud resources for applications to work and to carry out day to day operations.

Next, we will look at methods to control and restrict network traffic to and from your cloud environment.

atoms.title: ND063 C3 L2 06 Controlling Network Traffic
Controlling network traffic Notes
atoms.text:
### Ingress
Ingress can be required to access services and resources that are running in our cloud environment.

A few examples of ingress traffic are:
- Web application traffic comes from the internet to your web applications.
- Traffic comes from other cloud virtual private networks.
- Traffic comes from on-premise networks such as data centers or corporate offices for management, internal user traffic, or other application integration for hybrid cloud environments.

### Egress
We also need to be able to access the internet or other external networks for our applications to be able to function. We will call this egress.

Common egress destinations are:  
- Integrations with other cloud based APIs.
- Application API traffic to AWS cloud services.
- Downloading patches, etc.
- Sending monitoring and metric data to external tools.

### Controlling Access
Ingress traffic can be controlled and restricted using network ACLs, security groups, which are both effective firewalls, routing rules, and host based endpoint security tools which oftentimes contain firewall capabilities. 

In addition to the configuration of ACLs and security groups, private access to VPC networks is also required, either from user work locations or from corporate-owned network spaces.

Egress traffic in AWS is generally handled using internet gateways and nat gateways. As with ingress traffic, egress traffic should also be controlled and restricted for a number of reasons.

atoms.title: Controlling network traffic New Terms
atoms.text:
### Key Terms
#### Ingress
In-bound network traffic that is entering your cloud environment from the outside.

#### Egress
Out-bound network traffic that is leaving your cloud environment.

#### Internet Gateway
Network component that is part of a VPC. Facilitates out-bound and in-bound traffic to the internet.

#### VPN
Extends a private network such as an AWS VPC to an on-premise LAN or a user’s local host.  VPNs are encrypted tunnels that traverse the Internet.

#### Direct Connect
A dedicated and private network link between a company's on-premise local network and an AWS Direct Connect location. Enables two-way traffic between AWS resources and the local network. 

#### Network ACL (NACL)
Firewall construct in AWS which allows controls to be placed on VPC subnet network traffic.

#### Security Group
Firewall construct in AWS which allows controls to be placed on individual resources that are deployed in a VPC.

question.prompt: Which of the following actions would reduce the chances that an attacker could establish a network connection directly to a cloud host?

answers.text: Do not allow outbound internet access from the host.
Ensure that the IAM role for this instance is the least privileged.
Restrict inbound traffic by only allowing connections from trusted networks.

atoms.title: Restrict Access to Cloud Resources Heading
atoms.text:
## Restrict Access to Cloud Resources

The use of firewalls will provide the ability to granularly restrict and control network traffic to and from cloud VPCs, subnets, instances, databases and other resources which reside in the private IP space of your VPCs.

atoms.title: ND063 C3 L2 07 Restrict Access To Cloud Resources Walkthrough
Restrict Access to Cloud Resources Notes
atoms.text:
Our goal should be to limit and restrict connectivity to specific IP ranges and ports.

This is traditionally done with the use of firewalls. In the cloud, there are a number of ways that we can implement firewall functionality.

### 1. Host based firewalls 
Host based firewalls allow server admins and developers to define at the operating system level specific inbound and outbound sources and ports.
### 2. Firewall appliances 
Commercial Firewall products or appliances can also be deployed in cloud environments.

atoms.title: ND063 C3 L2 08 Using Security Groups And Network ACLs
Network ACL and Security Group Notes
atoms.text:
### 3. Network ACLs 
Network ALCs can be applied at a subnet level and allow you to add multiple firewall rules.
### 4. Security Groups 
Security groups are a second layer and by far the most utilized tool to restrict traffic to and from your cloud hosts and instances

Most cloud native patterns will at minimum tend to use a combination of NACLs and Security groups.

### General Guidelines for using ACLs and Security Groups
- Know and define your trusted networks for your source and destination traffic.
- Apply ACLs for incoming traffic to all subnets based on trusted networks. 
- Apply Security groups to instances based on the role or functionality of that instance or application.
- For both Security groups and NACLs, following the principle of the least privilege only allows traffic from specific hosts or IP ranges to specific ports. 
- Determine the default Security group for a VPC.

atoms.title: Restrict Access to Cloud Resources New Terms
atoms.text:
### Key Terms

#### Security Groups
A set of network control rules that can be applied at the instance or resource level.

#### Network ACL (NACL)
A set of network control rules that can be applied at the network subnet level.

atoms.title: Restrict Access to Cloud Resources Additional Resources
atoms.text:
### Further Reading

- [AWS NACL Documentation](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/vpc-network-acls.html)

- [AWS Security Group Documentation](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/VPC_SecurityGroups.html)

atoms.title: Restrict Access to Cloud Resources Easy Quiz

answers.text: Security groups do not have explicit deny rules, whereas NACLs can.
They are effectively the same.
NACLs can not be applied to an entire subnet or subnets, they can only be applied to an instance.
Security groups can be applied to a specific instance, whereas NACLs are applied to an entire subnet.

atoms.title: Restrict Access Example
atoms.text:
### Question 2
Your company has provisioned a database instance in AWS.  We would like to configure Security Group rules to secure this database.

The following are our connectivity requirements:

- The database has been launched in a private subnet with a CIDR block of 10.10.1.0/24.   
- The database listens on TCP port 3306.
- Applications which need to connect to the database are running in a separate subnet with a CIDR block of 10.11.3.0/24. 
- The mentioned application instances have been launched with their own security group sg-123456.  
- There are other servers in the application subnet which should not be able connect to this database. 
- The data engineering team who has a source IP range of 172.16.0.0/8, also needs to be able to connect to the database on port 3306.

atoms.title: Restrict Access to Cloud Resources Exercise Instructions
atoms.text:
## Configure Security Groups and ACLs

In this exercise, you will choose a VPC and public subnet in your AWS account to setup a new NACL and security group and test both.

1. Setup a new public subnet in your VPC for this exercise.

2. Create a new Network ACL for the VPC.

3. Observe the inbound and outbound rules for the newly created NACL.

4. Associate the new NACL with the new public subnet you have created.

5. Create a new security group in the same VPC. Do not add any rules at this time. Note down the security group name.

6. Determine your public IP address (Hint: Google *what's my IP*).

7. Launch a linux EC2 instance into the public subnet you have created. Assign it a public IP address and the new security group that was created.

8. Attempt to ping the EC2 instance on its public IP address.

9. Attempt to ssh into the EC2 instance.

10. Update the NACL. Add an **inbound** rule, number 100, allowing TCP traffic. All ports (0) all IPs (0.0.0.0/0).

11. Add an **outbound** rule, number 100, allowing all traffic, all ports, all IPs.

12. Although your ACL now allows SSH, attempt to SSH and ping the instance. Neither should work since the security group has not been updated.

13. Update the security group to allow SSH connections from your public IP address.  Also allow ICMP traffic from your public IP address.

14. Again attempt the SSH connection, the connection should succeed (you don’t need to login).  Attempt the ping, it will still fail since we haven’t allowed ICMP traffic on the NACL.

15. Update the NACL. Add a rule to allow ICMP traffic from all IPs.

16. Try the ping again. This time it should succeed.

18. Update the NACL. Remove the outbound rule that allows all traffic. Now the outbound portion of the NACL should be a simple deny all.

19. Attempt the ping and SSH again. Note that they no longer work since the return traffic has been blocked by the NACL.

19. Re-add the NACL allowing all outbound traffic. Verify that connectivity is restored.

20.  Add an explicit deny in the NACL. Deny your IP inbound TCP connectivity on port 22.  

21. Attempt the SSH connection again. Notice that it no longer works.

atoms.title: Egress control Heading
atoms.text: ## Egress Control

atoms.title: ND063 C3 L2 10 Egress Traffic To The Internet
Egress control Notes
atoms.text:
**Using NACLs and security groups to restrict internet bound traffic to specific entities is not the best approach.**

AWS provides a few different conduits for connecting to internet sites from our VPC subnets:
- Resources deployed in a subnet can be assigned to public IP addresses and will have internet bound traffic routed through an "internet gateway".  
- A NAT instance or NAT gateway can be deployed in public subnets so that instances in other subnets can use this device to gain access to the internet. 

From a security perspective, it is not practical to deploy all application resources that require internet connectivity into a public subnet. This widens the attack surface and leaves the environment open to exploitation.

To solve this, a device such as the NAT gateway is the most common solution.

The shortfall with the NAT gateway solution from a security perspective is that it is difficult to monitor and restrict traffic at the application layer to specific domains and sites. 

### Securing Egress Traffic

atoms.title: ND063 C3 L2 11 Securing Egress Traffic
Securing Egress Traffic Notes
atoms.text:
### A Few Solutions

- **Set Up a Web Proxy Layer**: 
This is the simplest way to log application internet traffic. Proxies can also be used to restrict traffic to allowed sites. There are a few drawbacks:

 1. Additional Configuration: applications and instances that require internet access will need to be configured to make use of an http proxy. 

 2. The proxy farm itself will need to be configured, managed and maintained.

- **In-Line Gateway Appliance**: 
These appliances generally come from commercial vendors and provide a range of capabilities for controlling and inspecting outbound traffic out of the box.  Cost is the biggest barrier to this approach.

- **Host-Based IDS**:
A host-based IDS is an agent based solution that runs on each instance. Providing many of the capabilities that the in-line gateway appliance provides including egress control and data loss prevention, intrusion detection and prevention. The biggest disadvantage is enforcing that  all hosts in your environment have the agent running.

atoms.title: Egress control New Terms or Vocabulary
atoms.text:
### Key Terms
#### Network ACL (NACL)
Firewall construct in AWS which allows controls to be placed on VPC subnet network traffic.

#### NAT Gateway
A NAT Gateway is an AWS managed network component which allows instances in private subnets to connect to the Internet but does not allow connection attempts from the Internet to reach private instances. 

#### Proxy Layer (or Proxy Farm)
A set of HTTP proxy servers designed to handle Internet-bound HTTP traffic.  This solution provides additional visibility and control of which Internet sites can be reached.

atoms.text:
### Additional Resources
We highly advise [this article be reviewed in detail](https://aws.amazon.com/answers/networking/controlling-vpc-egress-traffic/).

atoms.title: Access to Cloud Networks Heading
atoms.text:
## Access to Cloud Networks

Previously, we talked about obtaining console login access to cloud servers and instances. Oftentimes, developers and engineers will need to establish network connectivity with these hosts and other hosts running in private subnets, such as RDS database instances, etc.  

Here, we will outline a few methods for establishing network access to resources running in your cloud environments.

atoms.title: ND063 C3 L2 13 Access To Cloud Networks
Bastion Hosts Notes
atoms.text:
### Methods for Establishing Network Access to Resources Running in your Cloud Environments

#### Bastion Hosts 
Bastion hosts, or jump hosts, are set up in a public subnet to allow a user to login from either their home or office network, and subsequently access or jump to resources in private networks. 
- Pros: It is a simple and low cost method for getting onto your cloud VPC.
- Cons: It needs additional effort to harden the bastion host. It is not scalable for many users, and may not work if client applications need to be on the user's laptop or desktop. It is a common target for attackers who hope to gain access to the network by exploiting a vulnerability on the bastion host.

atoms.title: Bastion Hosts Image
atoms.caption: **Bastion Hosts**
atoms.alt: A diagram showing someone using a Bastion Host to work from home.

atoms.title: Virtual Desktop Notes
atoms.text:
#### Virtual Desktop Solution
Similar to a bastion host, except that each user will get their own virtual bastion.
- Pros:  It allows users to install their desktop application clients in the cloud environment without having connectivity to the VPC from their local laptop
- Cons: It costs more than a bastion host. Users will not have direct connectivity to any backend services in the VPC.

atoms.title: Virtual Desktop Image
atoms.caption: **Virtual Desktop**
atoms.alt: A diagram showing virtual desktops in use.

atoms.title: Client VPN Notes
atoms.text:
#### Client VPN 
A client VPN solution allows a user to connect to the cloud VPC using a secure VPN client to establish an encrypted tunnel. 
- Pros: Easy to set up. It has the ability to manage many users and roles. It places the user into the VPC so that they may use client applications on their local host to hit the resources deployed in the VPC.
- Cons: It has additional cost as compared to a bastion host. Users may need to install proprietary VPN clients on their local machines.

atoms.title: Client VPN Image
atoms.caption: **Client VPN**
atoms.alt: A diagram showing VPN clients in action.

atoms.title: Site to Site VPN Notes
atoms.text:
#### Site-to Site-VPN
We can connect a local trusted network's firewall with the AWS VPN service to establish VPN tunnel connectivity from the entire local network to the AWS VPC network.
- Pros: No need to install any VPN client software on each user's local machine.
- Cons: Additional routing and configuration needs to be performed on the local network. It often leads to delays in setup. No role based routing.

atoms.title: Site to Site VPN Image
atoms.caption: **Site to Site VPN**
atoms.alt: A diagram showing site to site VPNs in action.

atoms.title: Access to Cloud Networks Notes
atoms.text:
#### Direct Connect Link 
A dedicated link from a corporate office network or co-location datacenter.
- Pros: Dedicated bandwidth. It is ideal for hybrid cloud environments.
- Cons: Higher costs and require more time to set up. Once set up, if users are not on the corporate LAN, a solution such as VPN or VDI will still need to be implemented. Generally, it is not an option for small or virtual teams that do not have a LAN to work out of.

atoms.title: Access to Cloud Networks Image
atoms.caption: **Direct Connect Link**
atoms.alt: A diagram showing direct connect link in action.

atoms.title: Access to Cloud Networks New Terms or Vocabulary
atoms.text:
### Key Terms:
#### Bastion Hosts 
Bastion hosts, or jump hosts, are set up in a public subnet to allow a user to login from either their home or office network, and subsequently access or jump to resources in private networks. 

#### Client VPN 
A secure tunnel between a user's local host and a VPN server in a cloud VPC. The tunnel is established using a VPN client running on the user's host.

#### Sit- to-Site VPN
A secure network tunnel between a local trusted network and the AWS VPC, using the AWS VPN service or other VPN product.

#### Virtual Desktop
A desktop deployed in a cloud VPC that can be used to run applications that need connectivity to resources in the VPC. A user would install a virtual desktop client on their local host to connect to and use the virtual desktop.

#### Direct Connect
A dedicated and private network link between a company's on-premise local network and an AWS Direct Connect location - enabling two way traffic between AWS resources and the local network.

atoms.title: Designing an Architecture Heading
atoms.text:
## Exercise: Designing an Architecture

In this exercise, you will start with a simple reference architecture and use the design principles outlined in the lesson to improve the security posture of the environment.

atoms.title: Designing an Architecture Instructions
atoms.text:
Refer to a simple reference architecture and use the design principles outlined in the lesson to improve the security posture of the environment.

For your convenience we have provided a starter architecture diagram file in "draw.io" format.
The file is available via [AWS S3 and is named "cand-c3-l2-architecture-design.drawio"](https://cloud-architect-nanodegree-program.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/cand-c3-l2-architecture-design.drawio).

You may import this file into [draw.io](https://app.diagrams.net/) (or [Lucidchart](https://www.lucidchart.com)) and make the necessary updates.

This environment contains the following components:

- VPC with an internet gateway
- Public subnet hosting a NAT gateway
- Application instance Kubernetes cluster running our application containers in a private subnet.
- RDS database - Postgres - deployed in a private subnet
- Internet facing load balancer to accept web traffic (80 and 443) - deployed in a public subnet.
- Security groups assigned to the load balancer, instances, and RDS database.

Your assignment is to improve the architecture so that it meets the following requirements for security and access:

1. Developers need network connectivity to the Kubernetes cluster to manage on 6443. They do not need to login to any instances.

2. Application containers need connectivity to the database on Postgres port.

3. The data science team needs access to the database as well. They do not need access to the application cluster.

4. The applications will need to connect to an external service such as Mailgun. At this time, we don’t know Mailgun’s IP ranges or what other services the application will need to connect to.

5. We want to monitor network traffic from the application containers out to the internet.

6. All access needs to be the least privilege. Security group rules should be as specific as possible.

7. Team members do not have access to a corporate network.

You may either complete a new version of the diagram or a writeup outlining each layer of security that you would incorporate into this design.

Be sure to be specific about chosen tools and products and how they would help make this environment more secure.

### Hints and Approach
- Fine tune each security group to only allow access from IP ranges or security groups which need access. Ensure ports are specific.
- Stick with a bastion or VPN client based approach to allow team members access to the environment. A new security group should be set up for the VPN clients or bastion host users.
- Research container based IDS/IPS/host monitoring solutions, aqua, sysdig, alertlogic, twistlock are notable products. Just include a few sentences on how the chosen tool might meet the requirement.

Add internet connectivity solution to control and monitor connections to internet sites such as [mailgun.com](https://www.mailgun.com/).
Identify additional tooling for security monitoring related to the application containers running in the kubernetes cluster.

atoms.title: ND063 C3 L2 15 Lesson Conclusion Video
Lesson Conclusion Text
atoms.text:
### What We Learned
In this lesson, we have explored a number of different methods to ensure secure access to cloud infrastructure and resources.

- We have looked into methods for providing secure login access to cloud hosts and instances.
- We have discussed the importance of controlling and restricting network traffic, including incoming ingress traffic and outbound egress traffic. We also reviewed tools and products to help facilitate this.
- We looked at methods for providing engineers secure network connectivity with cloud resources deployed within the cloud VPC.

atoms.title: Glossary
atoms.text:
### Glossary
#### Key Pair
A key pair consists of a public key and private key that authenticate and encrypt an SSH session. The public key can be hosted on cloud servers and the private key is held by the user. Only a user with the private key that corresponds to the public key will be able to authenticate to the SSH server.

#### Privilege Access Management (PAM) Tool
A privileged access management tool provides management of authentication, sessions, password storage, audit, and privilege escalation when it comes to logging into server infrastructure.

#### AWS Systems Manager (SSM)
The AWS Systems Manager service provides the ability to manage EC2 instances at the operating system level - including patching, command execution, automation, state management, inventory.

#### Session Manager
Session Manager is a feature within AWS Systems Manager which allows an authenticated IAM user or role the ability to start a terminal session on an EC2 instance.

#### Open Vulnerability
An exploitable vulnerability in the OS kernel, packages, or applications installed on an instance which could lead to a remote actor gaining unauthorized access.

#### Immutability
A deployment model where components do not undergo any changes from provisioning to deprovisioning.

#### Immutable Instances
Instances that are launched from pre-configured images and do not undergo any changes from deployment to deprovisioning.

#### Configuration Management Tool
Tools that can enforce operating system configuration state based on versioned code templates.

#### Intrusion Detection System (IDS)
A process that monitors system activity and identifies suspicious behaviour indicating that a server has been compromised.

#### Security Information and Event Management (SIEM)
Tools that aggregate system events and logs in order to provide historical and real-time analysis, correlation, dashboards, and alerting.

#### Ingress
In-bound network traffic that is entering your cloud environment from the outside.

#### Egress
Out-bound network traffic that is leaving your cloud environment.

#### Internet Gateway
Network component that is part of a VPC that facilitates out-bound and in-bound traffic to the internet.

#### NAT Gateway
A NAT Gateway is an AWS managed network component which allows instances in private subnets to connect to the internet but does not allow connection attempts from the internet to reach private instances.

#### Proxy Layer (or Proxy Farm)
A set of HTTP proxy servers designed to handle internet bound HTTP traffic.  This solution provides additional visibility and control on which internet sites can be reached.

#### VPN
Extends a private network such as an AWS VPC to an on-premise LAN or a user’s local host.  VPNs are encrypted tunnels that go over the internet.

#### Direct Connect
A dedicated and private network link between a company's on-premise local network and an AWS Direct Connect location - enabling two way traffic between AWS resources and the local network.

#### Network ACL (NACL)
Firewall construct in AWS which allows controls to be placed on VPC subnet network traffic.

#### Security Group
Firewall construct in AWS which allows controls to be placed on individual resources that are deployed in a VPC.

#### Bastion Hosts
Bastion hosts, or jump hosts, are set up in a public subnet to allow a user to login from either their home or office network, and subsequently access or jump to resources in private networks.

#### Virtual Desktop Solution
A desktop deployed in a cloud VPC that can be used to run applications that need connectivity to resources in the VPC. A user would install a virtual desktop client on their local host to connect to the virtual desktop.

#### Client VPN
A secure tunnel between a user's local host and a VPN server in a cloud VPC. The tunnel is established using a VPN client running on the user's host.

#### Site-to-Site VPN
A secure network tunnel between a local trusted network and the AWS VPC, using the AWS VPN service or other VPN product.

#### Direct Connect
A dedicated and private network link between a company's on-premise local network and an AWS Direct Connect location - enabling two way traffic between AWS resources and the local network.
